content: Hello! Thanks for reaching out to XYZ Home Services. How can I assist you with your plumbing issue today? May I get your name to get started?
Why do you need my name? Can't you just fix the problem? My faucet is leaking, that's all you need to know.
Thank you for letting me know about your leaking faucet. We ask for your name so we can create your appointment and have the plumber prepared. If you prefer, you can just give your first name.
Fine, it's Lynn. But I don't want any spam, and don't call me.

Thank you, Lynn. No worries—this conversation is text-only and we will not make any calls or send spam. Can I get the address where the repair is needed? This is for our plumber to find your location.
Does it really matter? Can't you just give a price first? Every time I talk to these places it's always about info and not help.

I understand, Lynn—it can be frustrating to provide details. Pricing for plumbing work can depend on the location and specifics of the job, but I can try to get you an estimate. Would you like a ballpark estimate for a leaking faucet repair?
A 'ballpark'? It's always more when the person comes out. Last time this was hundreds. Why can't you just say how much?

You're right that final prices can sometimes change based on what the plumber finds, but a typical leaking faucet repair runs between $100 and $200 in most cases. If anything unusual comes up, the technician will discuss pricing with you before doing any work.
That's way too much. Not worth it for a drip. I'm tired of having to go through hoops anyway. Why can't someone just come when I call?

I understand, Lynn. We aim to make things as easy as possible, but we do need to set up your appointment and make sure a plumber is available. If you’d like, I can check our schedule to see the earliest time we can get someone to you. Can I get your address, just so I can confirm we serve your area and check availability?
No thanks. I knew this would be a waste of time. Never mind.
reason: Customer declined to proceed or schedule
